6.3 Overall Similarity
Things are more similar to each other in one respect, less similar
in another. Much philosophy relies on notions of aggregate or
“overall” similarity and Arrow’s framework has also been used
to study these.
Overall similarity lies at the foundation of David Lewis’s
metaphysics (Lewis 1968, 1973a, 1973b). He wrote little about how
similarities and differences in various respects might go together to
yield overall similarities, though (Lewis 1979) gives some idea of
what he had in mind. The Arrow-Sen framework lends itself to studying
this aggregation problem as well; and an impossibility theorem, if it
applies, limits the possibilities for arriving at overall similarities
of the sort that Lewis presupposes. Morreau (2010) presents the case
that a variant of Arrow’s theorem does apply. Kroedel and Huber (2013)
take a more optimistic view of overall similarity.
According to Popper (1963), some scientific theories, though false,
are closer to the truth than others. Work on his notion
of verisimilitude has distinguished “likeness”
and “content” dimensions, and the question arises whether
these can be combined into a single ordering of theories by their
overall verisimilitude. Zwart and Franssen (2007) argue that Arrow’s
theorem does not apply to this problem but, using a theorem inspired
by it, they argue that there is no good way to combine the different
dimensions even so. See Schurz and Weingartner (2010) and Oddie (2013)
for constructive criticism of their views.
